item.title: ASP.NET Core Series: Performance Testing Techniques
item.description:
ASP.NET Core is a cross-platform, high-performance,¬†open-source¬†framework for building modern, cloud ready, connected applications.
In this episode, Ryan Nowak chats with Cecil about some tools and techniques for doing performance testing against your ASP.NET Core applications.
[01:52] - What should you really be testing? [05:26] - Setting memory constraints [07:45] - Collecting metrics with .NET counters [12:22] - Load testing tool options [15:20] - What do all these numbers mean? [18:38] - Getting setup with the .NET counters tool
ASP.NET Core Performance Best Practices https://docs.microsoft.com/aspnet/core/performance/performance-best-practices?WT.mc_id=ondotnet-c9-cephilli
ASP.NET Core documentation https://docs.microsoft.com/aspnet/core?WT.mc_id=ondotnet-c9-cephilli
Create a Web API with ASP.NET Core https://docs.microsoft.com/learn/modules/build-web-api-net-core?WT.mc_id=ondotnet-c9-cephilli
Bombardier https://github.com/codesenberg/bombardier
dotnet counters https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/diagnostics/dotnet-counters?WT.mc_id=ondotnet-c9-cephilli
item.author: (dotNET)

item.title: Lightweight alternatives to Google Analytics
item.description: More and more web-site owners are concerned about the "all-seeing Google" tracking users as they browse around the web. Google Analytics (GA) is a full-featured web-analytics system that is available for free and, despite the privacy concerns, has become the de facto analytics tool for small and large web sites alike. However, in recent years, a growing number of alternatives are helping break Google's dominance. In this article we'll look at two of the lightweight open-source options, namely GoatCounter and Plausible. In a subsequent article, we'll look at a few of the larger tools.
item.author: (June 17, 2020 This article was contributed by Ben Hoyt)

item.title: Sleep Hygiene For Software Engineers
item.description: Software engineers know the importance of sleep; posts extolling its virtues (or the problems associated with its absence) regularly reach the front page of HackerNews. In fact, around the time I finished this post there were two articles on the front page: Fitful nightly sleep linked to chronic inflammation, hardened arteries and Why Sleep Deprivation Kills. Yikes! There‚Äôs invariably a comment on sleep-related posts saying something to the effect of, ‚ÄúI know getting good sleep is important, but I don‚Äôt know why I‚Äôm not sleeping well and I don‚Äôt know how to resolve it even if I did!‚Äù. Academia offers little help as there‚Äôs only a handful of studies focusing on sleep solely for the software engineer.
item.author: (Scott Klum)

item.title: The Web Has Got Me
item.description: Last week, I decided to start tackling a problem I've had for a long, long time. Brain fog. It's been getting worse over the years - to the point that I don't realise time has gone by. I forget things instantly. A tipping point was recently being unable to work out a profit margin (rather embarrassing for all concerned!).
